intersections.value: There's an area in Table View where I can instruct the program to add a new feature to the project.
The intersection between a newly added feature and an existing feature, or two newly added features can be edited.

- Newly added features are reflected in the model.
- This is true even if no intersection has been edited since the addition of the new feature.
- If a new feature is added while the export view is shown, the view is update immediately.

- If a new feature is added while in focus mode, the new feature can be reached while cycling through the features.
- There is a button in the new feature add panel to add a feature and enter focus mode in one click.
Newly added features can be hidden.
The feature table immediately reflects the newly added feature.
If I type in a field other than the main diagonal, it'll appear in the transposition of the cell I typed into as well.

- If I edit an intersection, it's represented in the exportable model.
- If I edit an intersection while the export textbox is shown, the textbox updates immediately.
When editing an intersection in focus mode, we edit the intersection between the selected (fixed) feature and the currently showing feature.
Intersections where at least one feature is hidden cannot be edited (obviously). However if a feature has been hidden and then shown, it can be edited again.
When the text field state (of the export text) is changed, the intersections are reflected in the feature table (as long as the model is valid).
In Table View I can type in an intersection of two features.

There is a button that allows me to view a text representation of my project.
The button can be clicked and then a textbox appears with the text representation.
Export works the same way as in table mode (the new state is immediately shown if the text representation if visible).
Hidden features are exported as well.
Exporting and importing the model are symmetrical. I.e. I can get the project model to exactly the same state where I was if I export the project, reload the page, then import the model.

In Focus Mode there is no feature table, instead we can go through the other features one at a time.
- There are buttons to move to the previous / next feature (cycling).
- There is a button to return to table view

- Features that have been hidden in table view still show up in focus mode.
- The hidden / shown status of a feature in table mode is preserved after returning to table mode.

- When importing, if the import changes the currently focused intersection, that is shown immediately.
- When importing, if the focused feature no longer exists, the view returns to table view.
- When importing, if the intersection currently shown in the focus mode no longer exists, we go to the next feature that exists.
- When importing, if the import text is invalid, an error message is shown (the same as in table view)
- Focus mode can be entered using a button on the feature header in the feature table.
Features can be hidden in Table View using a button next to each feature column / row header. Hidden features show up in the side bar with a button allowing them to be enabled.
Importing (changing the text in the export/import text field) preserves the shown / hidden state of features currently in the table (as long as the model is valid).
Hidden features do not show up in Table View.
If I change the state of the text field showing the exported model I instruct the system to load the new representation.
When the text field state (of the export text) is changed, the features shown are reflected in the feature table (as long as the model is valid).
There is Table Mode in which all feature intersections can be seen.

Focus Mode lets the user focus on the interactions between a single selected feature and all the other features in the project.
This is especially useful when adding new features.
